title: TNNT: The Named Entity Recognition Toolkit

sentences.text: Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats.
Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions.

This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results.
The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.
NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text.
Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text.

However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use.

It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.
This paper introduces TNNT2 .

Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models.

TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip.
We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information.

The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools.

Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.
There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER.
To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.
TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1).
Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 .
These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text.
The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user.
All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.
For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities.
The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity .

A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution.
This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.
TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL.
Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools.
In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1.
The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2.

The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).
TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models.
Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task.
The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models.
TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text.
Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task.
Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 .
The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model.
Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3.
This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results.
Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.
TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models.
This tool is still in its early stages of development.
It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4].

There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks.

The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

summary:
Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats. Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions. This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models. TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results. The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.

NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text. Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text. However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use. It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.

This paper introduces TNNT2 . Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models. TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip. We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information. The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools. Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.

There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER. To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1). Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 . These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text. The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user. All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.

For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities. The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity . A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution. This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.

TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL. Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools. In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1. The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2. The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).

TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models. Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task. The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models. TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text. Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task. Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 . The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model. Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3. This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results. Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.

TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models. This tool is still in its early stages of development. It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4]. There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks. The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

Predicate-is_important_in.label: is important in
Predicate-is_important_in.description: The predicate 'is important in' indicates a relationship where the subject plays a crucial role or has significant relevance within the context of the object. It suggests that the subject is essential, vital, or necessary for achieving, understanding, or accomplishing something described by the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or offers something to someone or for some purpose. The object represents what is being presented, which can be an idea, concept, argument, data, or other information.

Predicate-automates.label: automates
Predicate-automates.description: The predicate 'automates' indicates that the subject performs or executes a specific process or task on its object, typically involving the use of technology to streamline, simplify, or replace manual procedures.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: The predicate 'integrates' indicates a process of combining or unifying multiple entities (represented by the object) into a cohesive whole, which is then connected to and influenced by the subject. This integration can be understood as a harmonious fusion, where individual components are brought together to form a new entity with distinct properties.

Predicate-takes.label: takes
Predicate-takes.description: The predicate 'takes' indicates that the subject entity accepts or receives something from its object. This can be interpreted as an action of acquiring, processing, utilizing, or being influenced by the object.

Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.label: is a major component in
Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a significant and essential role within or as part of the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject is an integral element contributing to the overall structure, function, or purpose of the object.

Predicate-given_the_existence_of_a_wide_.label: given the existence of a wide range of document formats
Predicate-given_the_existence_of_a_wide_.description: This predicate indicates that some condition or circumstance (the subject) has a significant impact on the feasibility or effectiveness of an action, process, or situation described in the object. In this case, the existence of various document formats affects the difficulty of extracting information.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates that the subject offers or makes available something to someone or for some purpose, connecting it with the object. In this general sense, providing implies a transfer of resources, information, or services from the subject to fulfill a need or achieve an objective.

Predicate-have_a_summary_of.label: have a summary of
Predicate-have_a_summary_of.description: To 'have a summary of' means to possess or be associated with a concise and condensed representation of something, typically conveying key information about that thing. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject (the entity being summarized) and the object (the resulting summary), indicating that the subject is related to or characterized by the summary.

Predicate-introduces.label: introduces
Predicate-introduces.description: Introduces refers to a relationship where one entity (the subject) presents or brings forth another entity (the object), often providing an initial overview, explanation, or context for understanding. This predicate typically indicates that the subject provides a gateway or entry point into the knowledge, concept, or idea represented by the object.

Predicate-is_to_automate.label: is to automate
Predicate-is_to_automate.description: The predicate 'is to automate' indicates a purpose or intention to apply automation processes to achieve a specific outcome, connecting the subject (the main goal) with an object that represents the process or task being automated.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: Indicates a state or characteristic that holds true about the subject. The predicate 'are' connects the subject and object by stating an equivalence, similarity, or identity between them.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship of utilization or application between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject entity employs, exploits, or makes use of the object entity for some purpose or function.

Predicate-are_based_on.label: are based on
Predicate-are_based_on.description: The predicate 'are based on' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Some of these models) relies on or has its foundation, principles, or methodology derived from the object (e.g., rule-based and statistical approaches). This connection suggests that the subject's characteristics, properties, or behavior are influenced by or rooted in the concepts, theories, or methods represented by the object.

Predicate-is_capable_of_processing.label: is capable of processing
Predicate-is_capable_of_processing.description: Indicates that a subject has the ability to handle or manage an object in some way. This predicate suggests that the subject possesses the necessary skills, knowledge, or resources to process the information contained within the object.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates a process of obtaining or selecting specific information from a larger body of text. It implies that the subject (MEL, for example) is actively retrieving or identifying relevant content within the object (All textual content), which can be understood as a collection of written material.

Predicate-is_processable_for.label: is processable for
Predicate-is_processable_for.description: The predicate 'is processable for' indicates that the subject has the capability or suitability to be processed according to some specific criteria or method, which is described by the object. In general, this predicate establishes a relationship between the subject and an external processing mechanism or system, suggesting that the subject can be effectively handled or transformed through such means.

Predicate-keeps.label: keeps
Predicate-keeps.description: The predicate 'keeps' indicates a relationship where the subject maintains or retains possession, control, or relevance over the object. This can imply a sense of responsibility, ownership, or continued attention towards the object.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject offers or makes available something (the object), often in the form of information, resources, or services. It implies that the subject has access to or control over the object and is willing to share it with others.

Predicate-keeps_general_statistics_of.label: keeps general statistics of
Predicate-keeps_general_statistics_of.description: The predicate 'keeps general statistics of' indicates a relationship where the subject entity collects and maintains aggregated information about the object concept. This connection implies that the subject has some level of responsibility or authority to gather, analyze, and store data related to the object.

Predicate-generates_an_integrated_summar.label: generates an integrated summary of
Predicate-generates_an_integrated_summar.description: The predicate 'generates an integrated summary of' indicates that the subject (a system or process) produces a concise and comprehensive overview of the object (entities, concepts, or information), integrating relevant details to convey key insights.

Predicate-retrieves.label: retrieves
Predicate-retrieves.description: The predicate 'retrieves' indicates that the subject acquires or obtains the object, often in a context where the object was previously inaccessible, unknown, or hidden. This can involve searching for, finding, extracting, or uncovering information, resources, or entities.

Predicate-provides_various_features_to_a.label: provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate
Predicate-provides_various_features_to_a.description: This predicate indicates that the subject offers a set of functionalities or capabilities that enable interaction with, manipulation of, or integration with the object. The features provided allow for accessing, expanding, complementing, and correlating the object in various ways, facilitating its utilization, analysis, or combination with other entities.

Predicate-performs_other.label: performs other
Predicate-performs_other.description: The predicate 'performs other' indicates that the subject (a system or entity) executes or carries out a set of tasks or functions that are not its primary responsibility, but rather belong to another domain or category. This relationship suggests that the subject has capabilities or resources that enable it to perform these additional tasks, which may be related to its core function or unrelated.

Predicate-apply.label: apply
Predicate-apply.description: To apply refers to the process of using or implementing a particular concept, method, model, or technique on a subject. This predicate connects the subject with an object that represents a means of achieving some goal or solving a problem.

Predicate-analyse.label: analyse
Predicate-analyse.description: To examine or investigate a subject (in this case, textual content) to identify patterns, relationships, or underlying structures. The predicate 'analyse' implies a systematic and intentional process of breaking down complex information into its constituent parts, often with the goal of gaining insight, understanding, or making informed decisions.

Predicate-integrated_with.label: integrated with
Predicate-integrated_with.description: The predicate 'integrated with' indicates a relationship of unity or cohesion between two entities. It suggests that the subject and object are combined into a single, cohesive whole, often implying a loss of individual identity or autonomy.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' indicates that the subject has a specific capability or functionality to perform an action or set of actions described by the object. In general, it suggests a relationship where the subject possesses or provides the means to execute the operations or processes specified by the object.

Predicate-is_integrated_with.label: is integrated with
Predicate-is_integrated_with.description: Indicates a relationship where two entities are combined or unified to form a new whole. This predicate suggests that the subject and object have merged their respective aspects, functions, or roles to create something more comprehensive.

Predicate-is_depicted_in.label: is depicted in
Predicate-is_depicted_in.description: This predicate indicates a representation or illustration of something (the subject), which is presented within another entity (the object). The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject is being visually represented, described, or portrayed in some way through the medium or format specified by the object.

Predicate-orchestrates.label: orchestrates
Predicate-orchestrates.description: To orchestrate means to carefully plan and coordinate a complex process or activity, bringing together different elements or components into a harmonious whole. In this sense, the predicate 'orchestrates' connects the subject (the entity responsible for planning) with the object (the thing being planned), implying a high level of control, organization, and attention to detail.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' indicates a conjunctional relationship between two or more entities, concepts, or phrases. It connects multiple subjects, objects, or clauses to form a cohesive whole, emphasizing their shared characteristics, properties, or functions.

Predicate-performed_for.label: performed for
Predicate-performed_for.description: Indicates that an action or activity was carried out with a specific purpose or beneficiary. The predicate 'performed for' suggests a relationship where the subject (the core analysis) took some kind of action, and its outcome or result was intended to benefit or serve the object (various NER models).

Predicate-identifies_entities_for_respec.label: identifies entities for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task
Predicate-identifies_entities_for_respec.description: This predicate connects a subject (typically an entity or system capable of performing Named Entity Recognition tasks) with its output object, which represents the results of identifying entities for specific categories. The predicate also captures additional information about the process, including start and end timestamps as well as the duration taken by the models to complete the task.

Predicate-gives_an_overview_of.label: gives an overview of
Predicate-gives_an_overview_of.description: The predicate 'gives an overview of' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a concise summary or introduction to the object, which typically represents a larger body of information. The connection between the subject and object is one of summarization or presentation, implying that the subject has some authority or expertise in presenting the key points or main ideas contained within the object.

Predicate-is_a_dataset_used_in.label: is a dataset used in
Predicate-is_a_dataset_used_in.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (a specific dataset or collection of data) has been utilized or employed for some purpose within the context described by the object. The relationship between the subject and object suggests a connection where the dataset plays a role in achieving, illustrating, or supporting the information presented.

Predicate-is_another_dataset_used_in.label: is another dataset used in
Predicate-is_another_dataset_used_in.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between a subject (a specific dataset or resource) and an object (another dataset), suggesting that the former is utilized or incorporated within the latter. It implies a connection where one dataset serves as input, reference, or inspiration for another.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: Indicates a state of possession or association between the subject and object. The predicate 'has' establishes a relationship where the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the properties described by the object.

Predicate-specify.label: specify
Predicate-specify.description: To specify means to clearly define or identify something by providing specific information about its characteristics, properties, or requirements. It implies a process of detailing or outlining the essential features of an object, concept, or system, often in order to clarify ambiguities, establish boundaries, or facilitate understanding.

Predicate-implement.label: implement
Predicate-implement.description: To implement means to put into effect or bring into practice a plan, method, or system. It implies taking an idea or concept and turning it into a tangible reality, often requiring effort, resources, and expertise.

Predicate-experiment_with.label: experiment with
Predicate-experiment_with.description: To engage in a process of testing or trying out different approaches, methods, or techniques to achieve a specific goal or understand a particular phenomenon.

Predicate-define.label: define
Predicate-define.description: To define means to establish or clarify the meaning of something by specifying its characteristics, boundaries, or scope. This predicate connects a subject (e.g., Users) with an object (e.g., the desired settings), indicating that the subject is responsible for determining or setting the parameters of the object.

Predicate-refines_and_improves.label: refines and improves
Predicate-refines_and_improves.description: The predicate 'refines and improves' indicates a process of enhancing or optimizing the quality, accuracy, or effectiveness of something (the object), typically through the application of expertise, knowledge, or advanced techniques by someone or something (the subject).

Predicate-allows.label: allows
Predicate-allows.description: The predicate 'allows' indicates a permission or authorization for the subject to perform an action with respect to the object. It implies that the subject has the capability or right to interact with, access, or manipulate the object in some way.

Predicate-traverse_and_retrieve.label: traverse and retrieve
Predicate-traverse_and_retrieve.description: To traverse and retrieve means to navigate through or explore a given space (physical or abstract), gathering specific information or data as one moves along. This predicate connects the subject, which initiates the traversal process, with the object, which represents the target of that process - in this case, NER results.

Predicate-can_be_found_at.label: can be found at
Predicate-can_be_found_at.description: Indicates that information about the subject can be accessed or obtained from a specified location or source denoted by the object.

Predicate-used_by.label: used by
Predicate-used_by.description: The predicate 'used by' indicates a relationship of utilization or application between two entities. It suggests that the subject (a tool, model, system, etc.) is employed or operated by the object (an individual, organization, entity, etc.). This connection implies a sense of agency or control, where the subject is being utilized to achieve some goal or accomplish a task.

Predicate-integrate.label: integrate
Predicate-integrate.description: To combine or unify disparate elements into a cohesive whole, often resulting in increased efficiency, effectiveness, or understanding. The predicate 'integrate' suggests bringing together distinct components to form a new entity that surpasses its individual parts.

Predicate-evolve.label: evolve
Predicate-evolve.description: To evolve means to undergo a process of gradual and continuous change or development, often resulting in significant improvement or transformation. The predicate 'evolve' connects the subject (the entity undergoing change) with the object (the aspect or characteristic being modified), indicating that the subject is transforming into something new or more advanced.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: To provide assistance or resources that enable the subject to accomplish a specific task, fulfill a particular role, or achieve a certain goal. The predicate 'support' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on the object for help, guidance, or sustenance.

Predicate-is_referred_to_by.label: is referred to by
Predicate-is_referred_to_by.description: The predicate 'is referred to by' indicates a relationship between two concepts where one concept (the subject) serves as the original or primary representation, and another concept (the object) represents an alternative or secondary reference point that corresponds to or points back to the first concept.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' connects the subject to an attribute or characteristic that defines its nature, identity, or classification. It indicates a state of being, equivalence, or similarity between the subject and the object, which can be a noun phrase, adjective, adverb, or even another verb.

Predicate-is_integrated_into.label: is integrated into
Predicate-is_integrated_into.description: The predicate 'is integrated into' indicates a relationship where one entity (the subject) has been incorporated or merged with another entity (the object), resulting in a unified whole. Predicate-The_motivations_behind_the_dev.description: The predicate 'The motivations behind the development of TNNT, a toolkit that automates named entity recognition (NER) analysis for unstructured information encoded in different document formats.' describes the underlying reasons or purposes driving the creation and use of a given tool or system. Predicate-is_integrated_by.label: is integrated by
Predicate-is_integrated_by.description: The predicate 'is integrated by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a system or entity) has its components or functionalities unified and organized under the control of another entity, which is represented as the object. Predicate-are_used_to.label: are used to
Predicate-are_used_to.description: This predicate indicates a purpose or function that something (the subject) serves for another thing (the object). Predicate-was_motivated_by.label: was motivated by
Predicate-was_motivated_by.description: Indicates that a subject's actions or decisions were driven by an underlying reason, goal, or stimulus represented in the object. The predicate 'was motivated by' establishes a causal link between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject's behavior was influenced or directed towards achieving something specified in the object.

Predicate-utilizes.label: utilizes
Predicate-utilizes.description: The predicate 'utilizes' indicates that the subject (a person, entity, or system) makes use of a resource, tool, method, or process to achieve a specific goal or outcome. The object represents the thing being utilized by the subject.

Predicate-has_enabled.label: has enabled
Predicate-has_enabled.description: The predicate 'has enabled' indicates that the subject has provided or made available something (the object), which enables a particular capability, process, or outcome to occur. In general, it suggests that the subject's existence, presence, or influence has facilitated the possibility of achieving or performing something.

Predicate-have_enabled.label: have enabled
Predicate-have_enabled.description: The predicate 'have enabled' indicates that the subject has provided a means or mechanism for achieving or facilitating an action, process, or outcome described by the object. In general, it suggests that the subject's existence, presence, or influence has made possible or simplified the occurrence of the event or state denoted by the object.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject has created an environment or condition where the object can function, operate, or be used effectively. It implies a causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject's presence or action allows the object to fulfill its purpose.

Predicate-process.label: process
Predicate-process.description: The predicate 'process' indicates an action or operation that transforms or handles a given input (object), often resulting in some form of output or modification. Predicate-processes.label: processes
Predicate-processes.description: The predicate 'processes' indicates a causal relationship between its subject and object, suggesting that the subject takes some action or performs an operation on the object. Predicate-was_developed_to_automate.label: was developed to automate
Predicate-was_developed_to_automate.description: This predicate indicates that something (the subject) was created or designed with the intention to perform a specific task or function automatically, as described by its object. Predicate-is_motivated_by.label: is motivated by
Predicate-is_motivated_by.description: The predicate 'is motivated by' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject's behavior or actions are driven by the underlying reasons, goals, or principles represented by the object.

Predicate-was_developed_to_automate_(1).label: was developed to automate

Predicate-allows_to_process.description: The predicate 'allows to process' indicates that the subject has the capability or permission to transform, analyze, or manipulate the object into a specific form or state. This allows for the processing of information, data, or content from the object.

Predicate-outputs.label: outputs

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or category of a more general concept, which is represented by the object.
